moves.1. Nf3:
This game is annotated in an entertaining way, from white's point of view. Some remarks could be interesting to beginners / intermediate players.

Striking opening: 1. Nf3!
Called the Reti opening in honor of chess player Richard Reti.
Usually the plan is that whatever your opponent does, you push the g pawn, fianchetto the light square bishop, then castle. In this way your king is well protected from the beginning.
It is considered defensive and not much used at top level.
moves.1... d5: 1 ...d5 Classic reply to the Reti opening.
moves.2. g3: Pushing the g pawn as scheduled.
moves.3. Bg2: Fianchettoing the light square bishop as scheduled.
moves.3... e5: Oh, black is controlling the center now.
moves.4. d4: Time to get dirty and go too!
moves.4... e4: Oh, he has a pawn on my side, and is threatening the knight.
moves.5. Ne5: Let's escape to e5! What do you think of this outpost?
moves.5... Bd6: What? Help, he's chasing my knight! I can protect him with the dark square bishop, or...
moves.6. Nxc6: That's it, let's take the knight. OK mine moved three times and his only one, but...
moves.6... bxc6: He has to alter his pawn structure to recapture. So, in terms of imbalances, so far I lost some tempos and he has an altered pawn structure.
moves.7. c4: OK now let's advance the c pawn to go to c5, if he captures, he will have a very bad pawn structure (three pawns on the same file, that can be good in some situations but here I'm not too sure), plus I can take the e pawn with the bishop.
moves.7... Be6: OK he doesn't take and develops his bishop, defending the d pawn.
moves.8. c5: So let's advance inside his side too, and attack his other bishop at the same time!
moves.9. Qa4: The c6 pawn is vulnerable, so let's threaten it. It's also interesting to have a diagonal targeting the adverse king.
moves.9... Qd7: He choses to defend with the queen.
moves.10. f3:
It would be good to get rid of this e4 pawn, who has already well walked.
If he takes I recapture with the e pawn, creating a semi open e file for a future rook.
Otherwise I just take with the f pawn, creating a semi open f file for a future rook.
moves.10... Nf6: Hmmm he choses to defend the e pawn by developing the knight. The problem is now, if I take, he will have a powerful knight on e4, defended by the d pawn.
moves.11. Bg5: I think it's worth sacrificing the bishop to kill the knight. He's defending d5 and e4, and he's well positioned if black decides to castle kingside.
moves.12. Bxf6: So... so long for keeping the bishop pair, bye bye Mr Knight. Say hello to Keat.
moves.12... Bxf6: Wisely, he recaptures with his bishop and not with the g pawn.
moves.13. fxe4: Now I can go with the initial idea and take the e pawn.
moves.13... dxe4: He recaptures, and I will be able to take with the bishop. But wait! Now he has two attackers targeting my d pawn, who is only protected by my queen! If he takes the d pawn, he will furthermore take the c pawn and destroy my center.
moves.14. e3: I prefer to build a solid diagonal spine of three pawns. The e pawn is not defended, but it's not threatened so far.
moves.14... Bd5: Of course he defends the e4 pawn, and now he also has a strong diagonal spine, with the bishop defending both extreme pawns.
moves.15. Nc3: His e pawn is still here, invading my side. My turn to develop a second piece threatening him.
moves.15... Qe6:
He moves his queen to defend e4.
At this point my impression is that the game is a bit stuck. The opening is over, we're in the midgame. Someone has to take the initiative.
moves.16. h4:
This move is probably not very good. The plan is to move on towards the black g and h pawns defending the king. On the other hand, my queen is a bit isolated on the a4 square, I should think of a way to put her back in the game... maybe Qd1?
Trading my knight against his bishop is tempting, but the drawback is that it would reorganize his pawn structure.
moves.16... Qg4: Damn, the black queen has taken advantage of the previous move. She threatens the g pawn now. Too late to bring back the white queen.
moves.17. Ne2: So far, I have no real plan to attack, and the only thing I see to defend the pawn is to bring the knight to e2. I have considered Kf2 too, but after something like Qf5 I wouldn't know what to do.
moves.17... a5: Now he plays on the queen side. It's likely I won't castle kingside, and he has a semi open file (b). On the other hand, I notice that his queen is a bit constrained, can we trap her somehow? If Bh3, her only free squares are h5 and g6. How to control them?
moves.18. Kf2: Commiting move, as I cannot castle anymore. The idea is that now it is the king who will protect g3, so I can bring the knight to f4 and control g6 and h5!
moves.18... Rfb8: He attacks the b2 pawn, threatening to arrive on the second rank.
moves.19. Qc2: Opportunity to move the queen towards the active side of the game, defending the b pawn.
moves.19... Rb4: He goes in. This is unpleasant, the rook is threatening to attack the queen by going to c4, I have to do something.
moves.20... Rab8: He doubles the rooks, threatening the poor b3 even more. I decide not to care and go on with the trapping plan.
moves.21. Nf4: OK knight moved to b4, good. But... the super plan doesn't work! If Bh3 then Qf3+.
moves.21... a4:
So black has now 4 attackers targeting b3.
One can see that if the b8 rook ever leaves its rank, I may be able to backrank-checkmate him.
moves.22. Rhb1:
So let's play Rhb1 with the strange idea:
axb3 axb3 Bxb3 Rxb3 Qxb3.
If Rxb3 then Ra8+ Qc8 Rxc8+ Bd8 Rxd8++!
moves.22... h6: Ooooooh he saw that and created an escape square for his king. No way! But wait, something appears: his e4 square is not defended anymore by the queen because the knight is now blocking the path. So...
moves.23. Bxe4: This move attacks the h7 square blocking the king's exit... At the same time there is still a b-plan to trap the queen with Bf5! It didn't work from the front, let's try from the back (sentence not to take out of context).
moves.23... axb3: OK he takes the b3 pawn. He could have taken the bishop as well.
moves.24. axb3: I recapture, the a file is now open! Ready to sacrifice the queen for a backrank mate.
moves.24... Bxb3: He still decides not to take the bishop and takes the pawn instead, threatening the queen. But it is a free bishop for me since after Rxb3, if Rxb3 then Qxb3.
moves.25. Rxb3: OK I capture the free bishop with the rook.
moves.25... Rb4xb3: And he recaptures. Here I have also considered Bf5 as mentioned earlier, but the problem is: Rb2 Qxb2 Rxb2+ checks the white king, so no time to bring the remaining white rook to a8...
moves.26. Qxb3: This leaves us with Qxb3, not so bad. If Rxb3 then Ra8+ leading to mate, and if he doesn't retreat the queen Bf5 is still trapping her. And I'm up materialwise.
moves.26... Qc8: This is probably the best move he could have played, at the same time defending the rook and saving the queen from being trapped.
moves.27. Bf5: Let's carry on attacking the queen.
moves.27... Qd8: He retreats. Now his rook is a threat to my queen as my rook can't go to the 8th rank anymore.
moves.28... Rb2+: The rook finally leaves the 8th rank, protected by the queen, to check my king. Not a big issue.
moves.29... g5: He attacks my knight with his g pawn. I think this is a mistake, as g7 is now empty.
moves.30. Bh7+: Let's go closer to the adverse king. If Kxh7 then Qxf7+ (taking advantage of the empty g7 pawn) which puts the king in a very uncomfortable situation.
moves.30... Kg7: He doesn't take and goes to g8. f8 was a better square, as I can now advance the knight and check him at the same time.
moves.31. Nh5+: Threats are too strong now, and I think that he doesn't have any real plan. He resigns.
